Putting the file on a USB stick and plugging that into the PS3 to play the movie will *NOT* remove the Cinavia protection.

I always put my movies on a USB stick to play them back on my PS3. This movie still has Cinavia protection and stops the movie from playback after about 5 minutes (no video or audio playback, just a complete halt with the nice Cinavia warning message on the screen).

When I run into a movie that is protected by cinavia I just burn it to DVD and watch it on my cheapo $29.99 DVD player and it works fine. But it will not play in a PS3 even if you burn it to DVD, or watch form a USB. I get the movie for free so if I occasionally have to deal with cinavia I don't freak out. But it would be nice if Sony would do something about it in a future update.

This worked for me. Try it and post results:

This worked for me.

1. Extract audio from Cinavia movie. I used Magix movie edit pro. Broke the link between sound and video.ï»¿ Exported the sound as .wav.

2. Then i opened the file in Adobe Audition 3.0. Opened Effect-->Time and pitch-->Pitch shifter to adjust the "pitch" to -1 and "cents" to 0.

3. Saved the file as .wav

4. Opened the program "Avidemux 2.5" and opened the Cinavia protected .avi movie. Go toï»¿ Audio-->Main track-->Audio source. Then chose your edited .wav file.

5. Save as xx.avi

Seems like lowering the pitch a notch escapes the fingerprint. If uploaders did this 15 min. procedure prior to uploading :) Excellent torrent btw.

Cinavia is copy protect software embeded in the file that mutes the sound after a period of time when streaming from your computer to the PS3. It is a pain in the ass. Many flatscreen hi-def televisions will not play computer input in a full screen mode. If you stream the media from your computer to the PS3 you get a full screen movie experiance without having to burn the file to DVD. When you do burn it the blue ray player will still not play the file properly. 
IF YOU SUBMIT A FILE WITH CINAVIA AT LEAST MENTION IT SO PS3 USERS WILL NOT WASTE THEIR TIME!
